jNetDev.Headers
Class jND_TCP

java.lang.Object
  jNetDev.Headers.jND_TCP

public class jND_TCP
extends java.lang.Object

jND_TCP
Class to model a TCP header. Fields are:

  • sourcePort - port number of the sender.
  • destPort - port number of the intended receiver.
  • sequenceNumber - sequence # for this packet.
  • ackNumber - ACK #
  • offset - where the data starts relative to the start of the header
  • reserved
  • ecn
  • flags - flags for the packet (SYN, FIN, ACK, etc)
  • window - window size for TCP
  • checkSum
  • urgent - pointer to urgent data
  • options
  • payload
The payload of the packet is NOT, strictly speaking, part of the header, but is a sequence of bytes following the header. 
 Header format:
    +---------------------------------+--------------------------------+
    |            sourcePort           |           destPort             |
    +----------------16---------------+---------------16---------------+
    |                          sequenceNumber                          |
    +--------------------------------32--------------------------------+
    |                             ackNumber                            |
    +--------------------------------32--------------------------------+
    | offset |reserved|ecn|   flags   |             window             +
    +----4---+---4----+-2-+-----6-----+---------------16---------------+
    |             checkSum            |             urgent             |
    +-----------------16--------------+---------------16---------------+
    |                      options                  |      padding     |
    +-----------------------------variable-----------------------------+

offset

public void offset(jND_BYTE1 offset)
Method to set the data offset of the header. There is no actual reason to set the offset, as it is calculated when the packet is built. The calculated value overrides any value set via this method.

Parameters:
offset - - the data offset.

sourceIP

public jND_IPv4Address sourceIP()
Method to retrieve the source IP address. The parse() method does NOT set this, as it is not actually in the TCP header. To retrieve this value, you should use the appropriate accessor of the IPv4 header class.

Returns:
the source IP address

sourceIP

public void sourceIP(jND_IPv4Address srcIP)
Method to set the source IP address. This is not actually included in the TCP header. However, it must be provided so that the build() method can calculate the checksum. The checksum for transport layer headers includes a pseudo header with the source and destination IP addresses in it.

Parameters:
srcIP - - the source IP address

destinationIP

public jND_IPv4Address destinationIP()
Method to retrieve the destination IP address. The parse() method does NOT set this, as it is not actually in the TCP header. To retrieve this value, you should use the appropriate accessor of the IPv4 header class.

Returns:
the destination IP address

destinationIP

public void destinationIP(jND_IPv4Address destIP)
Method to set the destination IP address. This is not actually included in the TCP header. However, it must be provided so that the build() method can calculate the checksum. The checksum for transport layer headers includes a pseudo header with the source and destination IP addresses in it.

Parameters:
destIP - - the destination IP address

parse

public void parse(byte[] pkt)
Method to parse a raw packet into its parts. This is a convenience method equivalent to parse(pkt, 0);

Parameters:
pkt - - the packet to parse.

parse

public void parse(byte[] pkt,
                  int offset)
Method to parse a raw packet into its parts.

Parameters:
pkt - - the packet to parse.
offset - - where in the packet to start parsing.

build

public byte[] build()
Method to build a packet for sending from its parts.

Returns:
a byte array which is the packet.
